task.title: Fix for Cold Solder Joints
task.shortdesc: Identify weak solder connections and reheat them to restore signal continuity.

prereq.p: You need a soldering iron heated to 650-700Â°F.

context.p: Cold solder joints create weak connections that cause intermittent or complete signal loss. You can identify these faulty joints by their appearance and fix them by reheating.

step.cmd: Inspect all solder joints for signs of poor bonding.
step.info:
Look for these indicators of cold joints:
Dull gray appearance instead of shiny silver
Grainy or crystalline texture
Blob-like formations with visible gaps
Cracks around the connection
step.stepresult: Cold joints look distinctly different from properly flowed solder.

step.cmd: Reheat each cold joint until the solder melts completely and flows around both the wire and lug.
step.stepresult: Properly reflowed solder appears shiny and smooth with no gaps.

step.cmd: Gently pull each wire to verify the solder connection holds firmly.
step.stepresult: The wire should not move or detach from the lug.

result.p: If sound is restored after reheating, cold solder joints caused the problem.
